description: From Middle English ȝerken (“to move suddenly, excite,  bind tightly, attack”), from Old English ġearcian (“to prepare, make ready”), compare ġearc (“active, quick”), from Proto-Germanic *garwakōną (“to prepare”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰrebʰ- (“to grab, take”). Cognate with jerk; see yare for more cognates.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A sudden or quick thrust or motion; a jerk.

verbs.description: yerk (third-person singular simple present yerks, present participle yerking, simple past and past participle yerked)

entries.meaning: To throw or thrust with a sudden, smart movement; to kick or strike suddenly; to jerk.
(obsolete, Scotland) To strike or lash with a whip or stick.
To bind or tie with a jerk.
